You weren't sure what you were going to end up looking like, until Kendra pulled out a mirror and turned it towards you.

There was still a bit of swelling from the softball, but the bruising was all but gone. Kendra really was a miracle worker. Though you noticed that she made a few embellishments that weren't strictly necessary.

"Kendra? Did I really need eyeliner and lip gloss?" you asked as you scrutinized your face.

"For the black eye, no, but I think it makes you look cute." Kendra giggled.

You felt a little embarrassed, boys weren't supposed to wear makeup, but then again, boys weren't supposed to have polished nails or go to a girl's summer camp either! And you can't say that it didn't feel really nice when Annie and Nora got back from their activities and complimented your new look, promising to give you makeup tips.
154331111111111111112111111111.title: A makeup bag

choices: You willingly jump into the lake
1543311111111111111121111111111.content:
The rest of the day was uneventful, which you were glad for, after the previous day's excitement and the excitement of the morning. You didn't realize you were such a klutz! Or maybe being forced to do this masquerade was throwing you off balance and you were inviting these instances of misfortune. Whatever the reason, you were hoping the softball to the face was the last misfortune you'd face. Maybe when you got home you could tell people that you won a fight! That would certainly help you regain all the masculinity that's been seeping out of you since you got here.

The next morning you woke up because you had been pelted with an article of clothing. You opened your eyes and sat up, finding a pink bikini had been thrown onto your bed.

"What's going on?" you asked.

"Today's swim day!" Annie chirped excitedly as she laid out her bathing suit onto her bed.

"Swim day?" you asked.

"Once a week, instead of the normal activities, we all go swimming in the lake, over by the docks. Swimming used to be an activity, but I think they had a lack of lifeguards, and figured it was easier to let us all do it at once." Nora explained.

"That's great, but I'm not really a swimmer." you said, both attempting to get out of wearing the bikini, but also a truth. Swimming was an activity that you loathed, especially when you'd go swimming at the boy's camp and the older boys would hold your head under as a joke.

You dressed in the same sort of outfit you'd worn in previous days, retaining the capris from yesterday, and went with the girls to breakfast. All of them had their suits on underneath their outfits, intending to get right in after eating. But of course, they escorted you back to the cabin and insisted that you change.

"Did I pack a different suit?" you asked out loud as you dug through the suitcase, hoping to find shorts or one of those suits with the skirt or something of the like.

"What's wrong with that? I think you'll look great in it!" Kendra beamed.

"It's just that... I have that thing... you know? Down there..." you pointed down.

"That's not a problem, just tuck." Annie said, almost off-handedly.

"Tuck?" you asked.

"Yeah, I've seen it on TV, you just sorta, hide all that stuff down there." Annie said.

What kind of TV do these girls watch? You'd never heard of such a thing, but if you knew anything about these girls, it was that they were stubborn, and would wait until you changed. You did what she said, and it seemed to work, not revealing any undue information.

After changing into the bikini, you slipped back into the sandals from the previous day, and followed the girls down to the docks where all the other campers were already having fun in the lake. Kendra, Nora, and Annie wasted no time jumping in while you stood at the edge of the dock, kicking your sandals off and placing them to the side.

"Come on in! The water's fine!" Kendra shouted.

"I don't know..." you muttered as you wrapped your arms around yourself, still self-conscious in the bikini.

How do you get into the lake?
1543311111111111111121111111111.title: The next day

15433111111111111111211111111111.content:
Being so focused on not jumping in, you didn't realize that Nora had snuck out of the lake and climbed back onto the dock, until you felt someone behind you and turned, only to be immediately shoved off the docks and into the water.

"Woah!" you exclaimed as you plunged into the water.

You immediately returned to the surface and spit a mouthful of water out. You wanted to be mad, but Kendra, Nora and Annie were laughing and splashing each other, and it was infectious. You smiled and joined in with the activities.

Turns out swimming was actually fun when you weren't being tormented and dunked against your will! There were some races that you took part in, you didn't win, but it was fun to try, and then there was a giant lake-set game of Marco Polo with the entire camp which was abject chaos, but the fun kind of chaos.

Your self conscious feelings vanished as you actually enjoyed the day more than you had ever enjoyed swimming at camp in your life before.

But that wasn't the only activity for the day, as not only was it "Swim Day" but it was also "Bonfire Night" and after dinner, the entire camp gathered around a bonfire roasting marshmallows. Carla remarked to herself how proud she was that the girl who spent so long trying to get out of the camp had finally come out of her shell and was enjoying herself.

Maybe this camp wasn't so bad. You looked to your left and saw Kendra grabbing another marshmallow out of a bag, offering one to you, which you accepted. You looked to your right and saw Annie and Nora giggling to each other as they talked. But you just had to bide your time until you could get out... right?
15433111111111111111211111111111.title: You're pushed into the lake

choices: You bring the letter to the main office
154331111111111111112111111111111.content:
One week later, you slowly opened your eyes as you heard the bustle of your cabin-mates getting ready. You stretched and got ready to greet the day. Your routine had gotten a bit faster, since you didn't have to brush your hair thanks to the help of one of the other campers, a girl named Izzy from Cabin 3, who had braided your hair during movie night into twin fishtail braids.

As the movie played, you looked around for the popcorn bowl, which had last been in Nora's hands. Nora didn't have it, but she was preoccupied with another camper who was working her hands through Nora's hair.

"Hey, Leslie, Izzy's gonna braid my hair, want her to do you when she's done?" Nora asked.

"I don't think so." you replied. "I don't think my hair is suited for braids."

"No way! Your hair is so cute!" Izzy exclaimed. "And braids are even cuter!"

Looking at the faces of the two girls, you couldn't help but be swayed to accept the offer. After all, braids can be removed, right?

Remembering movie night made you smile, since the braiding had been mostly convenient and you didn't have to worry about hair ties anymore. And you didn't get nearly as much forest junk stuck in your hair during hikes or bird-watching, which you had gotten better at since the last time.

After brushing your teeth, you looked yourself up and down in the mirror. What a difference a week can make! You managed to not have any more accidents, and your black eye had almost completely healed, but you still applied a bit of makeup at the behest of Kendra who insisted that you do it to keep your skin even. The lip gloss wasn't strictly necessary, but your lips had been getting chapped, and you didn't have any other type of chapstick.

Getting dressed, you had finally gotten back your old sneakers, but found the pink ones to be far more comfortable, so your old sneakers had been left under your bunk, untouched since their return. You quickly pulled on a pair of shorts and your Cabin 8 t-shirt, examining your nails as you pulled your shirt over your head. They'd gotten a tad longer, you might have to ask Kendra if she has clippers, though she'll probably want to do another manicure, which you weren't entirely against.

"Hey, Leslie! Isn't this that letter you sent to your mom?" Nora asked as she looked under one of the bunks.

The letter! You had completely forgotten about it because of the shower incident! You never sent it! And so you had been biding your time for nothing! How could you have been so stupid? You smacked your forehead and sighed.

"I left it here and must have forgotten to send it, then it got knocked under the bed."

"I'm sorry, that was probably me when I went to get your change of clothes on tie-dye day." Annie apologized.

"It's fine." you said. "It wasn't time sensitive."

You had been having so much fun... but maybe that was the takeaway. This was fun. You were enjoying yourself, enjoying being Leslie the girl and not Les the boy. This was going to take some deliberation.

"Why don't you go along to breakfast? I'll catch up." you said as you held the letter in your hands.
154331111111111111112111111111111.title: A week later

1543311111111111111121111111111111.content:
What should you do? You knew you were a boy, and you'd never had any sort of predilection for dressing like a girl, or liked girly things as a kid. You weren't the most athletic, and preferred books to sports, but you were never unsure about your gender. Until now. You hadn't ever been unhappy as a boy, or felt like you were in the wrong body, but the past week had shown that you were missing something, and you liked all the camaraderie and support that the girls gave each other that boys didn't for fear of being seen as "gay".

And the clothes were comfortable, which you didn't think at first, but after a week, you found yourself not minding any of the more form-fitting items designed for a body you didn't have, even if you were unnecessarily wearing a bra for breasts that would never grow, despite how Kendra, Annie and Nora kept insisting they would once you started hormones. You had fallen so easily into the role, what if that was the role you were meant to fill? More importantly, what happened to the real Leslie? Surely, she'd want her things back at the end of the summer. And why hasn't she shown up? Was she at the boy's camp pretending to be you? You imagine that'd be a bit tougher, but who knows?

You thought back to the breakfast conversation you had with your cabin-mates a few days earlier:

You giggled as Nora finished telling a funny joke, and Annie held a napkin up to her nose.

"Stop! Milk is coming out of my nose!" Annie cried.

"We should meet up after camp ends. I don't want to lose touch." Kendra suggested.

"We're definitely exchanging numbers. A shame we can't use technology here. I'd want to friend you all before I forget to." Nora added.

That technology ban was one of the reasons you were stuck like this. You'd be able to easily prove your identity with your cell phone.

"Where do you live, Leslie?" Kendra asked.

"Southtown." you replied as you took a bite of food. Not a lie, and it was a big place, though you worried that she might look you up after and find the boy you intended to return to being after you escaped.

"That's only about an hour away from Weston, where I live, I can totes take a bus to visit! Or vice versa!" Annie exclaimed.

You felt bad about leading them on, but what else could you do? Leslie wasn't sticking around, at least, the girl Leslie wasn't, but without your phone number, you'd never have to worry about seeing them ever again.

Your face fell as you realized what that meant. You actually enjoyed their company, and you wanted to remain friends, but you couldn't! Not as who you are.

"Something wrong?" Kendra asked, her face full of concern and worry.

"Nothing." you smiled. "Just thinking."

You had come to a decision. You knew exactly what you were going to do. You quickly marched out and headed for the main office. You had to call your mom.
1543311111111111111121111111111111.title: You weigh your options

15433111111111111111211111111111111.content:
As you walked towards the main office, you heard your name called from behind you. You turned around to see Kendra, Annie and Nora quickly trying to catch up to you. You stopped and waited for them to get close.

"Aren't you coming to breakfast?" Nora asked.

"They've got pancakes today!" Annie exclaimed.

You felt your stomach grumble, but this was a much more important matter.

"I'll be along, save me a plate. I've gotta call my mom." you said.

"You don't still want to go home, do you?" Kendra asked.

"How do you know about that?" you questioned. You'd never admitted to them that you wanted out at all.

"You spent the first few days frantically calling home, every girl does that their first time at a new camp." Kendra smiled. "But I'm glad you stayed."

"So am I." you grinned back.

This might be one of the toughest decisions, of your life but Kendra just made it real easy.

You quickly ran to the office and asked to use the phone. Carla was standing by and eyed you up and down as she deliberated on your request.

"Given that you've been a happy camper this past week, I'll allow it." Carla laughed and handed you the phone.

You quickly dialed in your home number and you felt your heart race as the phone dialed and rang.

"Hello?" came your mother's voice on the other end.

"Mom?" you asked. "It's me, Leslie."

"Les! Great to hear from you! After we got disconnected, I got worried, but I figured you were just having so much fun that you forgot to call back." your mom replied.

"Yeah, about that. I've got a lot to tell you." you started. "First things first, I got on the wrong bus. But that's okay!"

It was a lot to take in, but you think that she'll understand. Guess this summer wasn't such a bummer after all.


One Year Later:

You are Leslie Daniels. It's a family name, you were named after your great grandfather. You were a boy, though with your long hair and thin body you had been mistaken for a girl a few times, but now there was no mistaking anything. You're sixteen and heading for your first summer job, a counselor job at the camp that you had spent your last summer at. Your parents dropped you off bright and early at the pickup location before they had to go to work and you dropped your bag with all the other bags. You went up to one of the directors.

"Leslie! Great to see you back." Carla exclaimed.

"Great to be back." you smiled.

You were early, long before anyone else would show up. As you started to climb on the bus,

"Leslie!" Kendra exclaimed.

"Kendra!" you quickly ran to hug her.

"Don't forget us!" Nora shouted as her and Annie dragged their bags towards the growing pile of bags.

"How could I?"

"You've come so far since last year." Kendra admired.

"I know." you beamed.

"All right girls, ready for another year?" Carla asked as the campers started to arrive.

You had been uncertain last year, but as you prepared for another summer with your best friends, you knew that you had made the right choice.

The End
15433111111111111111211111111111111.title: Leslie's Choice

choices: Every one binges on sweets, an ignores the problem until morning.
Cabin 8 teams up and tells Carla or a more senior counselor
Annie says this is a girl's camp, you are a camper, so you need to be a girl..
Nora becomes your adoptive big sister, 'helps' you fit in.
Kendra, needs a new bff, as a trade off, you get protection.
1543311111112.content:
Kendra comes up behind, you and taps you on the shoulder.

"Come on slow poke, get your new PJ's on we are going have a getting to know each other gab-fest, and you as the new girl this year have the most catching up to do." Kendra says

Looking at you with more attention, then you are strictly comfortable with.

You shake a little under her directed gaze that only lasts for about 10 seconds, looking you up and down taking in your burrowed clothes.

"If you would feel more comfortable you could change in the Lavatory"

She and Nora point out the attached wash room, that is not much more then a set of sinks and a long horizontal mirror with 2 toilets at opposite ends of the room. And says "If you are not let comfortable with us yet"

Sighing you take the Night clothes and head for the wash room to make a quick change.
Closing the light wooden door, you lay the lavender night set down on the counter, checking first it is dry enough to safely put them down.

You , look in the mirror try to see why Carla will not believe you are a boy. All you can see is your skinny teen frame. Looking at the mirror the okay two thing that stick out is your slightly messy hair that could go either ways from your bus ride to the camp, and your 'borrowed' clothes
especially Annie's bra.

Why is it that Carla will not listen to you?
Are you that bad at being a boy that everyone takes you to be Leslie, a girl?

You, then slowly start to tear up for a few seconds. "But, I am a boy"

Trying to get your emotions together, you slap your face lightly, "Come on Man up", but as you trade your short and your t-shirt for the Lavender Pajamas, your heart is not into it.

You look at the mirror, and realize if you can not get this straighten out and fast. You are going to be stuck seeing your girlified reflection for a large chuck of the summer.

That thought is hard enough on you mentally that you quietly start to break down again, you just barely keeping it together.

A knock come from the door, "Come on and hurry up in there, I have to pee. You have been in there already, for 20 minutes. Some of the rest of us, girls need to be able to pee and get ready for bed too."

The loud knock, is all it took to send you over the emotional edge, and you finally let out a cracking moan and then a sob. ' There is no way you can be a girl for summer, and when everything comes to a head, you are going to be punished for some something that was not even your fault. '

"Come on and let me in" said Nora's voice though the door, "I want to help you. What is wrong?"

"Nothing, it wrong!" you cry out, "Beside, you will not believe me, no one else does."

"You will not know if you do not try and tell me." Nora implored back

"Fine, but I tried to warned you." Leslie opens the bathroom door, and tries to to leave

"Nope, you are not going any where, Missy until you say what is going on, or you have had a good long cry with us. We are going to be sharing Cabin 8 all summer."

The taller red-head, has you more then a little bit intimidated. You are there for gob-smashed/surprised when she lowers her shorts and panties together and just sits down on the toilet and keeps talking.

"Leslie, what ever is going on we like can relate, Annie wants to be at music camp intend of here, Kendra would love to be hanging out at the pool with her friends back home, I am likely the only one who is excited to be here until we get into the swing of things. After all my parents want me to engage more with other girls. Hence sending me to a camp, for girls" Nora continues almost unperturbed of the effect she is having on Leslie

Leslie's mouth drop open some, with the surrealness of the monument, thereby stopping his crying. He quickly turn around to face the other way.

"See, hearing about other people's problem has gotten you to stop crying. So how about we both wash up some at those sinks, and go talk about your issues, with the other girls."

Leslie hears some sounds from behind him, like toilet paper being unrolled, some wiping, and a flush.

"Come on wash those tears away, and we can talk." then laughing "I think Kendra, snuck some chocolate bars in with her luggage. Chocolate will make things seem better."

Nora and Leslie, wash up and return to the main cabin area. Kendra and Annie are now leaning over a glossy magazine. Talking about famous people and fashions that they wear.

"Hey, umm.. I have to say..Girls there is some thing you should.." Sighing, after a few false starts you get out. "Annie, Kendra, while I was in the bathroom, Nora found me and I am was crying. I have some things you need to hear."

"Why were you crying? What is wrong? Did a gal from camp 7 give you the business, do not worry, I will get her for you?" Kendra says both protectively and a bit of gusto. "No one messes with my crew of friends"

"Is this about your lost bag? I told it is okay I have, more enough clothes, I do not mind sharing outfit(s) for a camper in need. It is what the camp manual, says we should do for a camper in trouble." Annie replies, with both kindness and compassion. Though the last little bit sound to Less, as more a need to follow the rules.

"Well girls there is some thing I have to tell you and when I told Carla when we got off the bus and again when we came back from dinner. Well, she did not believe me. In fact when I said I could prove it she said my file says I am known to be a trouble maker, that is just not true. In fact I rarely get in trouble with my parents or at my school before summer break." Leslie implores them to at least believe in their new cabin-mate and hopefully friend.

"Well what is it? Secrets are for sharing." Kendra adds, sensing some deeply juicy gossip.

Nora makes sure you know she is there for Leslie, by holding on to his right shoulder. "I look out for my friends, we will clear things up between you and Carla, little sister"

"Wait a second, Carla is not here, and if they are fighting we need to hear both sides of the story. After all, Carla is the lady appointed by the camp to look out for us." Yep, Annie may be right brain creative and arty, but something says she follow the rules.

Taking a deep breath this may blow up in your face soon after wards but you got to tell them it is only fair.
If no one believes you from here on out, that is at least a point in your favor that you tried to make them aware of the mix-up, you are pretty sure happened.

"Before we get to what is an emotional story, Kendra why don't you break out some of those chocolate bars, you are famous for 'importing' in to the camp." Nora target a comment at Kendra.

Kendra puts out a separate small duffel bag from under her bed, unzipping it, it is fill to nearly over flowing with various sweets. She then hands out a few treats, to each of the cabin residence.

" I am not suppose to even be at this camp, I was sent to the wrong bus when I checked in at the busing, pick up center. The Lady at the desk the Director after asking my name told me bus #2, so I got on our shared bus and fell asleep. Just ask Kendra she saw me on the trip up on the camp bus."

"So, you clearly are at the right camp, Carla and the Camp Director both said your name was on the bus and camp lists, your parent must have switch your camp application and forgot to tell you." Annie adds

"Annie I wish it was that simply, and my bag is still on it way here. But, you see that is super unlikely to be the answer, because there is one other thing that you got to know if I am in this Cabin." -breath- "I am a boy..and this is a girls only camp"

"Oh, my gosh that is a big reveal, are you sure you are a boy?" 'Big Sister' (not your real sister) Nora asks in startlement

" Are you kidding me, this is one of the greatest prank ever pulled and the old ladies did it to them selves" Kendra expounded

"No, no, definitely not, my mother and uncle would not approve, this is a female only zone, they do not even let men up to the camp to be non-cabin counselors" Annie adds, in a broken fashion.

"You said you can prove you are a boy, do you have some id or something?" Kendra ask excitedly

"Well, no I was just going to show Carla, my private bits, and tell her I have get to the other camp." You explain your (naughty) plan of action.

"Well, this is so crazy, a story it must be true" Nora comments sadly

"So, what are we going to do about this? She is a boy. Just having her here could be trouble" Annie moans

"I think we should keep this going for as long as possible" Kendra adapts "And I can watch 'her' back. "

"Well I think we should call Carla and/or the 'Madame' * to rug on a mix of this big a mistake." Annie's brain kicks back in to gear "That or we will be the Cabin with a girl, that does not know how to be a girl and needs to taught how to be a girl, like everyone else at camp"

Nora thinks this over and does not seem put off of either idea, even Annie may not have meant it as a real suggestion. "Well if we can not get Carla on board with what is going on, how about we each teach Leslie a few things about being and acting like a girl."

"Ah, guys.. I mean ladies, don't I get a say in if I become a girl" Leslie asked with some worry.

"Yes, but we all are now in on this and it is likely you are going to get out voted." Kendra looks around and gets some nods.

"So lets take a vote, for what we are going to do."

* nick name for the camp director
1543311111112.title: Try and come clean, to your cabin mates

154332.content:
A Haunting Experience: You and your roommates start renting a house that was the site of a tragic accident that killed the previous tenants, a woman and her two daughters and soon, you find yourselves assuming their roles.

Fem Note: A vengeful person is given the power of a magic notebook that when a man's name is written in it, they are turned into a woman.
154332.title: Something else

1543321.content:
You finished dragging the last box into the house from the car as your two roommates followed suit and you shut the front door and looked at your new place.

"We did it guys, our new rental. Three bed, two bath, and dirt cheap." you said.

"It's only dirt cheap because the last tenants died, Steve!" Jeff, one of your roommates said.

"Did they say how?" your other roommate, Ed, asked.

"Gas leak, I think. Anyway, now we have to divide the rooms." Jeff said.

"I call master bedroom!" Ed shouted.

"Darn!" you said.

"All right, I guess we'll pick from the two other rooms." Jeff said. "Let's go bring our stuff up there."
1543321.title: A Haunting Experience

15433211.content:
You and Jeff walked upstairs and looked into the rooms. All the furniture and possessions of the previous tenants were still in there. The first room was very subdued, having belonged to the tenant's older daughter, who was probably high school age. The room was painted a pale blue and the girl didn't seem to have been overly girly, with lots of sports apparel in the room, most notably lacrosse gear. The other room was as if the color pink had vomited on a room, and had belonged to the tenant's younger daughter, who was probably around grade school age, with a lot of stuffed animals and tea party sets. You and Jeff had the same idea.

"I call the first room!" you both shouted at the same time.

"I say flip for it." Ed said, grinning.

"Fine. Call it in the air." Jeff said. He flipped a coin.

"Heads!" you said.

The coin landed and Jeff looked at it.

"Damn it!" he shouted.

"Ha!" you laughed. "Good luck in here, princess."

You walked back through the hallway to your room and started to unpack.
15433211.title: To the bedrooms

154332111.content:
That evening Jeff headed from the master bedroom, you took the teenage girls one and Ed took the little girls bedroom and you all went to sleep.

At about midnight the previous tenants returned in spirit form..

About a year earlier they were all killed by a gas leak but it wasn't their time, so they stayed on Earth instead of going to the spirit world.

The mother was 33 years old and was called Hannah Edith Williams she worked full-time plus she was a very caring mother to her two daughters.

Her to daughters were the oldest daughter Francine Annette Williams whom 16 years old and was a tomboy and loving sister and daughter, plus a star sports player in soccer, lacrosse and was a black belt in kick boxing.

Her youngest daughter was 6 years old and called Amelia Zara Williams and she enjoyed ballet, dance and gymnastics, she adored her big sister and loved both her sister and mother.

When midnight struck they all entered their rooms and found the boys in the beds..

What did they do?
154332111.title: Later

1543321111.content:
"Oh yuck," the ghost of Francine said as she observed Steve's body, sleeping in her bed. "This gross old guy is in my bedroom. He's touching all of my stuff."

"Calm down, Francine," her mother said. "This hasn't been our house for nearly a year now."

"I don't care, it's not right. What kind of grown-ass freak just sleeps in a teenager's bed?"

"Young lady, you watch your mouth. Ghost or not, I am your mother, you will not speak like that in front of me." Hannah said with an imposing whisper. She didn't know whether the sleeping men could hear spirits or not. She wouldn't risk it. Hannah wasn't going to let her family be exorcised.

Francine huffed in begrudging acceptance. She was doomed to remain eternally sixteen years-old. She would always be under her mother's thumb. "I want to haunt them. Can we haunt them, please? Scare them off like a Casper cartoon?"

"We've been over this, Francine. No hauntings. If nobody rents this house, they'll just wind up bulldozing it. Then where will we go?"

"I don't care. Anything is better than this. I can't eat, I can't sleep, I can't watch TV, or text, or chat with my friends. God knows where my phone is now. Probably scrapped for precious metals. And nobody comes by to mourn anymore. All I ever get to do is just hang around in the dark with my mom and my dork of a sister until the sun comes up."

"Well I'm sorry," Hannah said with growing weariness. "Next time my family dies, I'll make sure it happens at the mall."

Francine pouted and folded her arms in a huff. Or rather, she would have, had she still possessed lips and arms. Hannah and her daughters were more ethereal presences than floating bodies. "So that's it then? Just give up? Roll over and let three old guys move in?"

"First," Hannah said, "stop calling them old. They're younger than me. Or rather, younger than I was. Younger than I had been?" Hannah had been dead for over a year, but never determined the proper grammar for her situation.

"I'm getting distracted. Second, this house isn't a museum. I'm amazed the realtors didn't throw everything out once the house went back on the market. We don't need our stuff anymore, and we can't touch any of it anyways. Lord knows your sister tries. She's spent the last 14 months trying to play with her dolls. I had assumed you had more sense than her."

"But it's all my old trophies, and my journals, and my uniforms!" Francine protested. "I don't need to touch them, I just need to be able to see them. Not even see them, just know they're there. Same with my yearbooks, all the photos of my friends, the love letters I kept from middle school, my homecoming dress, that sweater grandma knitted for me... and..." she trailed off, trying her hardest to compose herself.

Hannah hadn't seen her daughter's face since the night they died. She didn't need to see it now. She knew the stubborn, teenage attitude was a mask for a sensitive, loving girl. Hannah and Francine were dead. But the tragedy was the inability of a mother to wipe away her child's tears.

"I'm sorry, honey. I am. This is rough on all of us. But they're just possessions gathering dust. You need to let go."

Francine sighed. "It's like I'm dying all over again. The first death was just my body. But the second death is everything else. Everything I ever was. I'm still a person right now. A dead person, but a person. Tomorrow morning, some stranger is going to take my entire life, and throw it into a garbage bag. I die again. First a deteriorating corpse, now a deteriorating memory. Mom, please. There must be something we can do."

Hannah paused, collecting her emotions and thoughts. "There might be..."
1543321111.title: Become Territorial

15433211112.content:
"Well, this is different," Ed said as he entered the kitchen.

"What's wrong?" Jeff asked.

"You're up first, and you're cooking. Normally, you roll out of bed at noon and eat cereal straight from the box."

Jeff was fully invested in making a stack of french toast. For some reason, the craving seemed impossible to ignore. He rolled out of bed with the sun, ignoring his tired body. Breakfast was the only thing on his mind. Of course, french toast was mostly prep work; it was just as easy to make two slices as it was to make half a loaf. And if Jeff was up so early anyways, he may as well celebrate the occasion by making enough for everybody in the house.

"It's just a little breakfast," Jeff said. "Don't make a big deal of it."

"So what are your plans for today?" Ed asked, stacking up his plate with rich, delicious slices of bread.

Jeff shrugged as he fixed his own plate and sat down at the table. "I dunno. Maybe see if I can't get the wi-fi up and running. Or at least the cable. How about you?"

"How about me?" Ed asked with contempt. "I'm going to work. I have a job. Like most people are supposed to have. Especially people who just bought one third of a house."

"Hey, I may be unemployed, but I can pay my bills. Don't you worry about that." Jeff came from a rather well-to-do household. His parents were quite well-off, and granted him a weekly allowance that surpassed the wages of any entry-level job in the state. Jeff was gifted an easy and comfortable life. He was going to enjoy it. Still, not a day went by without somebody nudging him to take on more responsibilities and become a better person.

"Can you at least do some work around the house today?" Ed asked. "Maybe dust, or vacuum? Seeing as you got the big bedroom and all, you owe us that much."

"Fine, I'll go to the store, pick up some cleaning supplies and some more food. But I'm not cleaning the whole place myself. You and Steve are going to help."

"Yeah, yeah..." Ed always resented his friend's rather lackadaisical attitude. He earned everything he had, and it wasn't very much. He'd love a life of easy leisure. He'd love to be free of responsibilities.

Ed took a sip of coffee as he shot his friend a cold glare. He had to fight from spewing it out across the table. "Oh god, that's terrible. What did you do to the coffee?"

"What are you talking about?" Jeff asked. "I didn't do anything to it. It tastes fine."

"It's so bitter," Ed said, scooping spoonfuls of sugar into his mug. "You really can't taste that?"

"Steve and I drank half the pot before you even woke up. It's fine. That's just how coffee tastes."

Ed tried another sip and made a disgusted face before pouring the contents of his mug down the sink. For whatever reason, coffee just tasted like gnarly, noxious mud this morning. "There's probably soap in the mug or something. I'm taking off for work. Can I be excused, please?"

Jeff looked at his roommate confused. "Um, yes? What the heck, man?"

Ed blinked, trying to get his head around things. "I don't know. I'm tired. Thanks for the breakfast. It was... yummy." He grabbed his portfolio and headed out to his car, trying to make sense of his odd choice of words.

"Weirdo," Jeff thought. He shrugged it off and went to work cleaning the dishes and stove top. Ordinarily, Jeff would have let them sit, covered in crust until the sink began to overflow. Now, as a homeowner, he felt an overwhelming sense of obligation. Like he should take pride in his surroundings.

And not just his surroundings, but his appearance. Jeff showered, shaved, and groomed himself until he deemed himself presentable. Rather than simply throw on the first shirt he pulled from his drawers, he took time to coordinate an entire ensemble. He even found an ironing board to press his garments.

Grabbing his keys, he set off to the store, ready for a big day of shopping and housework.
15433211112.title: The following morning

choices: Check in with the guys at dinner
Check in with the ghosts at dinner
154332111121.content:
Jeff parked his SUV and walked into the supermarket. He loaded up his shopping cart with the basics, or at least what he considered basics: white bread, peanut butter, macaroni, and packs upon packs of Ramen. Looking down at the assortment of salt and preservatives, Jeff felt a twinge of guilt. He wasn't just buying food for himself anymore, but his roommates too. He owed them an obligation. He tossed some apples into the cart to round things out.

He stared at his groceries in disbelief. Why was this so hard? He wasn't exactly a gourmet chef, but he managed to live this long without dying of malnutrition. Surely he had been doing something right. But why was standard diet seeming so strange and unappealing now?

Jeff meandered aimlessly through the aisles looking for any sort of inspiration, as though it were shelved between the canned tomatoes and beans. Turning a corner blind, he bumped into the cart of a strange woman. She looked noticeably older than him, though only about ten or fifteen years. She didn't seem aged or decrepit, but experienced.

"Oh, I'm so sorry," she said. "Are you okay?"

"Yeah, yeah. I'm fine," Jeff said. "It's my fault. I wasn't looking."

The woman purveyed the contents of Jeff's cart as she righted herself. "How old are they?" she asked.

"What?" Jeff asked, confused.

"Your kids. How old are they? My kids used to eat like that too," she said, gesturing at all the junk food in his cart. "They complained anytime I cooked anything without a microwave. They gagged at the appearance of anything green. They lived on pepperoni and chicken nuggets for a month straight. One night, I felt tempted to sneak into their bedroom and slip vegetables into their mouths while they slept." She laughed at her own joke.

"Oh, actually..." Jeff couldn't bring himself to correct the woman. He had been living on his own for years, and he still ate like a slovenly, bachelor couch potato. Looking at it from another's perspective, it was downright shameful.

She interrupted his train of thought. "You know, this grocery store offers a bunch of cooking classes. If you need some inspiration on how to cook for the little ones, me and a few other parents could offer some insights."

"Oh, uh, yeah. Actually that sounds like a great idea. I might have to--"

"Great. Let me have your phone. I'll text you the details and we'll get everything set up with the other moms." Jeff reluctantly handed the stranger his phone. She added her name to his contact list and bid farewell. Jeff stared confused at the events which just took place.

'Madison Angstrom' read the brand new contact. Was this woman actually going to worm her way into Jeff's life? He was really just trying to be polite and humor the lady. And how long could he keep the lie up? He wasn't a parent. He didn't have kids. Jeff acted like a kid! He wanted to finish grocery shopping so he could go home and play video games. Eventually, Madison would figure things out.

Sure, the cooking class sounded like a good idea, but what the heck could Jeff have in common with some random suburban mom? Scratch that, what could Jeff have in common with a gaggle of suburban moms, all of whom were currently receiving his phone number and e-mail address? If they were all as 'friendly' as Madison, it would be a rough time.

Jeff took a deep breath and added some eggs into his cart. As he did, he noticed something strange was peeking out from underneath all the soup. He moved a few packets around and saw something red at the bottom of his cart. A bottle of wine had somehow found its way among his groceries.

He considered putting it back on the shelves, but ultimately decided against it. If the next few days were anything like today, he may need it.
154332111121.title: Jeff goes grocery shopping

choices: Jeff, who's getting a little more matronly
Steve, who's getting a little more adolescent
Ed, who's getting a little more juvenile
1543321111211.content:
"I don't believe this!" Steve said, barging his way through the front door. He threw his jacket on the ground and kicked the wall in frustration. "I don't friggin' believe it!"

"Quit yelling!" Jeff yelled from the kitchen. He was preparing frozen ravioli for him and his housemates. It wasn't haute cuisine, but it was a step up from frozen pizza bites.

"Hey," Steve said sticking his head into the kitchen, "I just got fired, all right? I'm angry! I'm going to yell."

"You got fired?!" Jeff asked, incredulous. "What happened?"

"Oh, I mouthed off to my damn boss again. The jerk had it coming. If he didn't fire me, I would have walked out. I'm sick of that place anyways."

Steve had always been a proud individual. He wore his accomplishments on full display, be it his sculpted physique or his prowess in sales. However, his pride was also his downfall. He never took losses well, he didn't like to compromise, and he always took criticism as a personal attack.

To say Steve was hotheaded was an understatement. As much as he craved the respect and admiration of those around him, he only cultivated an aura of fear. Ed and Jeff were his only real friends, and some days, they barely tolerated him. To put it simply, Steve did not play well with others.

"Well, that's just great," Jeff said. "Now both you and Ed are out of work."

"Ed got fired too?"

"They downsized his department. The guy never saw it coming. And he's not taking it well either. I think he's crying."

"That guy's off his damn rocker."

"Hey," Jeff said, "be nice to Ed. He looks up to you." To anyone else, such a statement may have sounded odd. But Steve was so conceited, he didn't see anything strange with such a revelation. Of course Ed looked up to him. Steve looked like he was carved from marble. Ed couldn't bench press fifty pounds. Ed was a shy software engineer. Steve could sell a boat to a Bedouin. Ed hadn't dated in months. Steve had thirty girls he could call right now.

"And another thing," Jeff said, adding sauce to the pot, "cool it with the potty mouth, okay?"

Steve was taken aback. "What do you care if I swear or not? And why are you wearing an apron?"

Jeff stared at his roommate as though he asked why he was breathing. "So I don't get food on my clothes? Are you going to stand there and sass me all night? Go get Ed. We need to have a discussion."

Steve rolled his eyes as he left the kitchen. Jeff set the table and spooned out servings for him and his housemates. He felt a little twinge of satisfaction at a job well done.

As the three men began eating, Jeff broke the silence. "So, we're in a bit of a sticky situation right now. We just bought a house, and now all three of us are out of work."

"One of us didn't have work to begin with," Steve said under his breath. Ed stifled a chuckle.

Jeff chose to ignore his roommate's snipe. "My point is, we have thirty days to find a way to make our next house payment. Otherwise we're out on the streets. We can't get our old apartment back, and nobody will rent us a new place if we default on our loans. Ed, do you have any prospects?"

"That's the problem," Ed said. "There was a non-competitive clause in my contract. I can't work for another software company for two years."

"Well, that's no good. But we'll fix this somehow. Steve, do you have any leads?"

Steve rolled his eyes at what he perceived as an asinine question. "Oh yeah, I got a whole briefcase full of job offers. I picked them all up on the drive home. I just don't know which one I'm going to choose: the job with the swimming pool or the job with the free ice cream machine."

"Sarcasm is not going to help us, okay? Listen, I know things seem bad, but they're not completely bad. I have enough money in savings for the next few weeks. But not enough for house payments. When you two get your first paychecks, we'll take care of that. Until then, we need to cut back on the frills."

"Like what?" Ed asked.

"Well," Jeff replied, "for starters, I don't think we can afford beer or pot anymore. In fact, I'm going to have to do all the shopping now. If you need anything, ask me, we'll budget it out. Second, Steve, you'll probably need to cancel your gym membership."

"Why do you get to decide what we can afford?" Steve asked.

"Because it's my money. When you get a job, you can spend it however you want."

Steve crossed his arms in a huff and slouched in his chair.

"I can sell my car!" Ed interrupted.

"You'd really do that?" Jeff asked.

"Sure! It's old anyways. It costs more to maintain than its worth. Besides, it's not like I have to commute anymore."

"You see? That's the spirit we need." Jeff placed his hand proudly on Ed's shoulder. Ed couldn't help but smile, knowing he helped.

"Finally," Jeff said, "and this is the one that's going to hurt, we're going to have to put off redecorating indefinitely. I know nobody likes living in a girl's room, but we can't afford new furniture or renovations right now. We can't even afford to have the old stuff hauled away." Ed and Steve nodded in solemn acceptance.

"There's probably more we can do, but that's a start. Tomorrow, we'll hit the streets and find work. It doesn't have to be lucrative. It doesn't even have to be dignified. It just has to put money in the bank until something better comes along."



Who will we follow on their job-seeking endeavors?
1543321111211.title: The guys eat dinner

15433211112112.content:
Reluctantly, Steve did indeed cancel his gym membership. However, he had no intention of abandoning his physical fitness. He wasn't too keen on aerobics, but it was free and it was still exercise. The following morning, he grabbed a pair of gym shorts, a tee shirt, and laced up a good pair of sneakers. He left for the park early, ready to get a good workout before his demeaning job search.

The first few miles were rather uneventful. It wasn't until a basketball rolled across his path that things became interesting.

"A little help?" came a voice from the nearby basketball courts. Steve obliged and chucked the ball towards the players. "Nice throw," said the voice again.

"Thanks," Steve said. "Shouldn't you be in school?" he asked.

"Shouldn't you be at work?" she shot back. She laughed, lighting up the conversation. "It's not even 8 AM. School doesn't start for another hour. You wanna play a bit?"

"Very funny," Steve said. He was a long ways away from his high school days. What would a bunch of teenagers want to do with him?

The girl insisted. "No, come on. We got an odd number of players. It'll be fun."

Steve shrugged off his hesitations. Running was getting boring; a little basketball would be a decent change of pace. Besides, being accepted by a bunch of teenagers was a boost to his morale. He may have been getting older, but he was apparently still pretty cool with the kids.

Steve ran up to the court, never noticing, (or at least not caring) the five other players were all girls. Steve felt happy to have made such an impression. All the girls exchanged phone numbers with him. His three opponents wanted a rematch. His two teammates weren't abandoning such a great player.

The lead girl tossed her sweat-covered towel into her gym bag. Steve learned her name was Leslie. She was completely open with Steve, never talking to him like he was a strange adult, but a peer. Perhaps she needed a mentor, or a coach or something, Steve justified. "Hey, we get out of school at three. Wanna meet up?" Leslie asked.

"Can't," Steve said. "I gotta hit the bricks. I gotta find a job, like, yesterday."

"Ugh," Leslie said. "My parents made me get a job at the mall last summer. It sucked. The customers are garbage, the boss spent half his shifts staring at my ass, and I'm only just now getting the smell of butter out of my hair. I never want to see another pretzel as long as I live."

"I was looking for something a little more professional anyways."

"But you know, I think Grenada's is hiring. They had a sign there the last time we went shopping."

"Grenada's? That store that looks like a tiki hut? Isn't that place kind of..."

"Expensive?" Leslie finished. The word Steve was searching for was 'fruity.' While Grenada's was a big hit in upper class teen demographics, the average man wouldn't be caught dead wearing anything they sold. "Yeah. Their clothes are expensive, but they are *so* worth it. Oh, you totes need to work there. You could get such a discount, I bet."

"All right, all right. I'll check it out," Steve said. Sales were sales. Steve could sell cars, appliances, insurance, anything. How hard would it be to sell some silk shirts?

Steve bid farewell to his new friends and continued his run. It was boring before, but now it felt almost lonely. He just wished he had someone to run with.
15433211112112.title: The high school basketball stars

choices: Jeff finds a possible job opportunity
154332111121122.content:
Jeff and Ed had been driving around, following up employment leads. Ed had sold his car that morning for a meager $800, and was now reliant on Jeff driving him everywhere. And today, the two were on a number of job interviews.

Jeff hadn't worn a suit in nearly three years, and the one he owned was bought from a resale shop. It fit him well enough, but not 100% proper. The cuff of the slacks ended about an inch above where his normal pants stopped, exposing more of his ankle than he liked. The jacket was tight on his waist and shoulders, but surprisingly loose in the chest. He kept it unbuttoned anyways, trying his best to look cool and casual in an otherwise oddly-fitting outfit. He undid the top three buttons of his shirt to further accent this attitude.

Ed had worn a suit everyday to work since he graduated college. As much as he wanted to find a new job, he couldn't pass up the opportunity to dress more casual. He wore a cherry red sweater over a crisp white shirt. Jeff urged him to dress a little more formally today, but Ed resisted. He even threatened to dress Ed by force, but Ed still resisted. Jeff didn't have time to argue. The sweater would have to do.

After a number of 'we'll keep your applications on file' interviews, the pair wound up at New Dawn Daycare. Neither had worked with children before, nor did they have any experience with social services. But the two needed employment, and the daycare needed employees. It seemed logical.

"Hello," Jeff said to the administrator. "We're here to talk about enrollment."

"You mean employment?" The administrator corrected him.

"Oh, yes. My mistake. I don't know where my head is." Jeff laughed off his slip of the tongue. Ed, meanwhile, sat squirming in his seat. Maybe it was nerves, but he couldn't seem to focus on anything the administrator was saying. He just felt bored, but strangely energetic. He wanted to go home.

The administrator looked over Jeff's resume. At least what passed as a resume. Aside from some hourly work here and there, he hadn't actually had anything resembling a career. He had no skills, no certifications, and his only education was a bachelor's degree in something called 'Independent Studies'. "I'm sorry," the administrator said. "You just don't have the relevant work experience."

"Well that's that, then. Come along, Ed." Jeff started collecting his things. He subconsciously reached for Ed's hand, as though he were trying to escort his friend from the room. Ed had been acting rather spacey today, Jeff reasoned to himself. He might just wander off if he didn't keep the man in tow.

"Now, hold on one second. You yourself don't have what we need, but Ed here is a different case. We just switched over to a new piece of enrollment software, and we're having a heck of a time adapting. Somebody with your experience in computers would be a valuable asset."

Jeff sat down, pleased with the news. "What do you say, Ed? Do you want to work here?"

Ed was busy watching a bunch of kids on the swing set outside the administrator's window. "You mean I get to come here everyday?" he asked, snapping back to reality.

The administrator told him, "Well, not every day, no. You need to be here when the kids arrive and stay until the kids leave. That's a ten-hour day, which means you only need to be here four days a week. I think it's Wednesday you'll have off."

"I'm sure we can work something out for Wednesdays," Jeff said. "I mean, concerning the use of the car. He can stay home, by himself, obviously." The words sounded wrong to Jeff, as though he were suddenly speaking French. Why wouldn't Ed by all right home alone? By himself. With no one to watch him. Where he could get hurt, or kidnapped, or accidentally start a fire.

The administrator paid no attention to the oddities around him. "Although, understand, the computers would only account to roughly 15% of your duties. The others would involve helping with the children. Supervising them, cleaning up after them--"

"And playing with them?" Ed interrupted.

"Yes, that too. But remember, you're going to be older than them, so you need to be a role model, not just a playmate."

Ed was bouncing up and down in his seat. He couldn't wait to visit tomorrow. This would be so much more fun than his old job. He'd get to play with kids all day. Ed couldn't remember the last time he got to simply play, with no obligations or other hang-ups.

Ed felt like a kid in a candy store. And there was no candy store.
154332111121122.title: New Dawn Daycare

1543321111211222.content:
"Hey, what's with the toilets?" Steve asked. The toilet seats in both bathrooms had been secured to the porcelain bowls. No matter how hard Steve pulled or tinkered with the locks, he couldn't lift them.

Jeff was cleaning the windows as Steve asked. He replied without breaking his gaze from his task. "Well, Steve, I don't want to point fingers, but somebody keeps aiming wide of the bowl. Since I'm the one who has to clean the bathrooms, I'm putting a stop to it. From now on, the three of us can do our business sitting down."

"Gross," Steve winced. "I was going to ask what's for dinner, but never mind."

"Could you empty the dishwasher for me, please?"

"Make Ed do it. I'm meeting some friends."

"Ed is busy. I asked you to do it."

"Ed's just watching cartoons."

"Ed is preparing for his first day at the daycare center," Jeff explained. The caretakers at New Dawn Daycare, advised Ed to familiarize himself with things kids are interested in. He needed to seem like less of a strange man, and more like a new friend.

Steve scoffed at the idea. "He's a little dork, you know. All the kids are going to make fun of him."

"You be nice to him. He's nervous enough as it is, and I don't want him getting kicked out of daycare. I can't keep driving him around all day. Now go empty the dishwasher."

Steve stuck out his tongue at Jeff, but dutifully went off to finish his assigned chore.

"I swear, that one's got such a mouth..." Jeff muttered to himself, putting away the cleaning supplies. Jeff took a little break before preparing dinner. Since Ed's cartoons were making the living room a noisy environment, Jeff recused himself to his bedroom.

The bedroom of the departed Hannah Williams was cozy, and remarkably comfortable. Jeff felt eerie on his first night, sleeping in the bed of a strange woman nearly ten years his elder. All her clothing was still in the closet, hanging alongside his own. Her shoes were still on the rack, alongside his own. Her jewelry, and her cosmetics, and even her toiletries were just as she left them. The realtors wouldn't normally leave perishables behind, but they felt almost compelled to do so.

With no one to haul this stuff away, Jeff tried his best to shove it aside. Although, he conceded, it seemed awfully rude. He would simply have to share the space. He rifled through some of the items stowed in the closet, looking for some way to maximize the efficiency of the cramped space. Doing so, he came across a briefcase.

Curiosity got the best of Jeff, and he opened the case, never wondering how he knew the code to the locks. Inside were some documents, some office supplies, and a file folder with a sticky note that said "important."

If this is so important, Jeff reasoned to himself, somebody might need it. Even after however much time its been. Jeff continued looking through the case, finding a business card for Hannah's old office. He dialed up the business, learning in the process it was a law firm. Explaining his situation, the office was happy to find the missing documents. The voice on the phone asked how they could repay Jeff.

Jeff explained his economic situation, and inquired if they had any open positions. Sure enough, they had an opening for an office assistant, and if he was interested, he could start tomorrow. Hannah, whose spirit was eavesdropping nearby, realized that Jeff was woefully unprepared for the duties of a law office. Even if he wasn't handling the cases, it required a certain level of legal knowledge. The firm would be in shambles if Jeff were to try and learn all the intricacies on his own.

Perhaps, Hannah thought, she could share her experiences as a paralegal? Jeff was certainly receptive to her influence already. In a few short days, he had nearly matched her proficiency as a homemaker and caretaker.

It wouldn't be hard at all to make Jeff into the working mom Hannah knew he could be.



Did Steve ever get that job at the mall?
1543321111211222.title: Jeff finds a possible job opportunity

You were in the New Mexico desert stargazing, alone. You had planned to bring along your girlfriend, but she dumped you only a few days earlier. You decided to come and camp out to get it off your mind. What you didn't expect to see was two guys disposing of a dead body.

And they didn't expect to see you either, since they immediately started chasing you. You were able to get to your car and drive away, but as you sped off, you hit... something.

The car flipped and you were barely conscious, barely able to feel your body when a bright light started to shine on your car. As you strained to see, your vision faded and you fell unconscious.

What you saw next was flashes of what seemed to be some sort of medical room and people... no, creatures, walking around and standing over you. The next thing you knew, you were waking up.

154332212.content:
Your eyes fluttered open as you got your bearings back. The first thing you noticed was that you were in a white room. And I don't mean a room with white walls and white floors, I mean, ethereally white. So white that you had at first assumed that you were in heaven. After your eyes adjusted, you tried to push yourself up, though your hands felt... daintier, when pushing against the bed.

You managed to put yourself into a sitting position and a mane of auburn hair fell over your face when you leaned to look at your body. You quickly brushed it away, getting to see your hands, which were indeed dainty, with manicured nails on each hand. You immediately tried to rush out of the bed, but you ended up falling face first onto the ground, with your fall being cushioned somewhat by a new weight on your chest.

You tried to scream, but you found that nothing was coming out. You stood up and tried to find a door, frantically banging on the wall. As you did, a door opened on the other side of the room and one of the creatures walked in. It was humanoid, though it was purple and had antennae on its head. You stepped back into the wall.

"We mean you no harm, human." the creature said.

You tentatively stepped forwards.

"Your transport was damaged and we found that your body was nearly beyond repair. We repaired your body using reference from your cellular device." the creature said. "Computer, activate mirror."

"Reference? Oh no..." you glanced into the mirror and saw your face... or rather what it was transformed into.

You hadn't changed your phone background since the breakup. It was a photo of your girlfriend, that you had rather liked, with her wearing a skimpy nightgown, and your old Deadpool mask that you had lying around. Thankfully the aliens seemed to understand the concept of masks, so your face wasn't Deadpool's mask.

You face was your own, though altered slightly, your lips were fuller, your nose smaller, your skin smooth. The rest of your body was similar to your girlfriend's. You looked in the mirror, you had a slim, slightly tanned, but also toned body. You had breasts, around a B-Cup and your male equipment had been replaced by the female equivalent.

"Are you unhappy?" the creature asked, as it noticed you frowning at the mirror.

You turned and nodded profusely.

"Why are you not... Oh, my! Your vocal cords must still be damaged. Allow me." the creature took out a device and waved it at your neck. It began to press buttons. "Try speaking now and tell me when your voice sounds right."

"What the... my voice... uh... testing...testing..." your voice began fluctuating between many different tones and pitches before it came across one that sounded like a woman's. "Oh!"

The alien stopped as it looked at why you had exclaimed. The device had given you a slight twinge of pain when it altered the cords.

"What the... oh my voice..." you started.

"Ah, now that you can speak, what is wrong?" the creature asked.
154332212.title: You wake up transformed into a woman

In the meantime, I know that humans have a tendency to prefer clothing. We have a device that can produce any manner of clothing and footwear, if you so desire it." the alien said.

The alien opened the door once again and you followed them out.

15433222112.content:
Your name is Kevin Hartford. You're 18 years old, and finally just graduated High School. About time, as spending four years there was truly arduous. At least you got through it, and you had plenty of good memories to go with it.

One of those good memories was meeting the girl who was now your girlfriend, Holly Kawaye. As her name implied, she had Asian ethnicity, but she was mostly raised in your hometown. Meeting her and becoming her boyfriend was a real joy. You guys did all that good stuff during senior year, including homecoming and all that. Yep, it was pretty good.

Naturally, you wondered how things would be going into the summer, but things hadn't been as hot. You both hadn't talked all that much since summer break started. You wondered if she was just busy getting ready for college or something, but that didn't sound like something she would keep a secret from you. Granted, there had been a few rocks in the relationship. Nothing big as far as you were concerned, just minor arguments that didn't really seem to lead to any major leak in the relationship.

Still, the silence was worrying. You had hoped to spend more time with her before having to go to college.

"Maybe I should try calling her again," you sighed.

You didn't want to harass her or anything, but you felt like you hadn't gotten to that point yet. With that, seeing how it was early in the morning, you picked up your smartphone and called her. You hoped that something good would happen.

And then....

154332221121.content:
When Holly finally picked up it was immediately obvious to you that she was upset. Whenever she gets angry her sarcasm goes way up and she sighs a lot.

"What's wrong?" You asked trying to be forth coming.

"Sigh.....You really can't think of a reason?" She said back to you.

"Uhh....no, what's going on?" You asked generally not knowing why she was unhappy.

"You insulted my family and my heritage Jerk!" She said with a puffy tone.

"What! No I didn't! When?" You asked a bit surprised.

"Remember last week when you came over to my family's house for dinner? You barely ate any of your meal and then you called our family shrine in the backyard a wishing well!" Holly said feeling insulted.

"I'm so sorry! I just wasn't very hungry I'm sorry. Also I thought it was a wishing well I didn't know it was a family ancestor shrine!" You said trying to defend yourself.

"Sometimes you can be so ignorant....I wish you could see things from my perspective sometimes." Holly replied.

"Listen I'm sorry how I can I make it up to you?" You asked.

"Why don't you come over and make an apology to my family's shrine first, then we will see." Holly said.

"Of course anything!" You said not wasting any time as you got in your car and drove off to her place.

You normally considered yourself a very open minded and tolerant person but it seemed like you had a small lapse of mindefulness that came off as offensive.

Once you arrived at Holly's she took you her back yard where the shrine was. There was a small pool in front of an altar with a stature of Buddha on it. Holly looked to you with a glare as she handed you a coin with some ancient Asian writing on it, however you couldn't tell what language.

"Here take this, get on knees and toss the coin into the pool. Then I want you to say. I wish I could see life from Holly's perspective." She said.

"Okay, sure no problem." You said just doing this to make her happy.

You followed instructions and got on your knees. Closing your eyes you tossed the coin in the pool and repeated the words.

"I wish I could see life from Holly's perspective." You said trying to be sincere.

Getting up you looked over to Holly who seemed pleased with you. "I'm sorry are we cool?" You asked.

"Almost....look into the pool it is supposed to tell your future now." She said.

Looking at the water you saw the ripples in the water and your reflection as it suddenly began to change. A new reflection suddenly began to appear. One of a very sexy Asian girl.

"Hmm....." Holly had her finger to her chin, seemingly deep in thought.

You weren't sure how to interpret her body language. Nothing she did betrayed her thoughts. Was she happy? Angry? Confused? Your guess was as good as his. She lightly paced back and forth from there, occasionally humming.

"Um...." you began, still confused.

However, just then, she finally turned to you, still looking passive.

"Well....I feel a little better at least," she said, hands on her hips.

Well, that was better than nothing. Perhaps it was now the best time to reiterate your apology.

"Really Holly, I'm sorry," you pleaded. "I'm sorry I made that stupid comment. I admit that I didn't realize how offensive it was, and I'm sorry. Can you please forgive me?"

You could have gone on longer, but you felt like that got the point across. Again, Holly's face was unreadable. Sheesh, it kind of frustrated you when you couldn't figure her out. In fact, it was frustrating enough that it was making your head itch.

Naturally, you reached up to take care of that, though as you scratched, you couldn't help but feel something off. Was your hair slightly bushier up there? In fact, were your ears being ticked a bit? You reached around your head, lightly feeling hair around your ears, like they were covered at the least. Huh, maybe it's been longer than you thought since your last haircut. You should probably get that checked out later. There were more important things.

"Well....I at least accept your apology," Holly said, maybe a ghost of a smile at the edge of her lips. "But...I think I'll need more time to completely forgive you."

Welp, it was a start at least. You were willing to let her take things at her own pace. Just do what you can to smooth things over and surely things will work out on their own.

However, from Holly's perspective, things were quite confusing. She wasn't sure what to expect when she commanded you to look inside. She perhaps figured maybe you'd see a reflection of herself, but she really didn't know. The shrine was somewhat of a mystery even to her. Looking up at the sky, she knew it to be around midday so far, to which she wondered if she should have you stick around longer.

1543322222.title: Something else

15433222221.content:
What amazing luck you were having! When your last apartment was condemned because the landlord was doing some shady activities, you had figured that you'd be homeless, but, as if by a miracle, you saw an online ad posting for a place not far from your old place that's in perfect proximity to your job. You immediately answered it and started to correspond with the person who posted an ad, a girl named Paige. You seemed to click and she agreed to a roommate interview.

Fast forward to the day of the interview, where you were impatiently hitting the buzzer in the lobby. You were the only person standing in there, though there was a girl standing inside looking just as impatient as you. She was a redhead, with long hair and freckles. She checked her phone before walking towards the door, opening it, and pushing past you to get outside. After a few seconds she walked back in, looking exasperated.

"Waiting for someone?" you asked.

As she opened the door to the main lobby, she turned around.

"Huh? Oh yeah, I'm supposed to be meeting a girl for a roommate interview but she hasn't shown up yet. I figured I'd meet her in the lobby." she said. "I take it, you have a similar story?"

"Yeah, I'm waiting for a tenant to let me in." you said.

"Usually I wouldn't do this, but I feel nice today." the girl said, holding the door for you.

"Thanks." you said.

You walked into the lobby with her and walked to the elevator. You got in and stood on the opposite side of the car.

"What floor?" she asked.

"Third." you replied.

"All right." she pressed the button and the car sped up to the third floor, where you got out, and so did she. "I really should call this girl."

The girl took out her phone and dialed a number. As she did, your own phone started to ring, you looked at who the caller ID was...

"You have got to be kidding me..." Paige said as you picked up the phone.

"Hey!" you sheepishly smiled as you answered the phone.

A little while later, you were sitting in her apartment at her kitchen table. There was an uncomfortable silence that Paige finally broke.

"So... you're Ashley." she said.

"Ash. You know, like Bruce Campbell?" you replied.

"Didn't you see on the ad that I was only looking for female applicants?" Paige asked. As you made eye contact you realize how striking her face really was.

"Uh, no, actually. Must've been in the fine print." you said. "Is that a problem?"

"I've had bad experiences with male roommates. And I'm not keen to try again." Paige said.

"What if I said I was desperate?" you asked.

"Still no. Sob story or not, you're still a guy." Paige replied. "It's a shame, cause we got on so well... if only..."

"I was a girl, yeah, I get it." you said. "I'll get out of your hair."

You stood up to leave and walked towards the door.

"I hope you find the roommate you're looking for, though." you said.

"Hm..." Paige mused as you opened the door. "Wait!"

"Huh?" you asked.

Paige jumped from her seat and rushed towards the door.

"You're not what I expected... but because we got along so well over email and you don't seem to be threatening at all... I'll give it ago. A 30 day trial period." Paige said.

"Wait, really?" you asked.

"I might regret this... but you might be the perfect roommate yet." Paige said.

With that, you spent the rest of the day and night getting everything packed. You weren't entirely sure how long you'd be gone of course, so you made sure to pack accordingly.

When the boat dropped the three of you off you saw signs posted guiding you to the center of the island. Following the signs you walked until you saw the an arch with a sign that said “Welcome Winners!”

Walking through you saw what you had hoped to see. A beautiful tropical resort. Several different huts all lined up with different things. There was a full service bar, a massage lounge, Steam room, hot tub, pool, volleyball, etc. everything you wanted.....except....well...girls.

Your eyes suddenly widened as several of the other guests looked over at each other wondering what was going on.

Barry looked down to his photo of a beautiful Hispanic girl and three other guys looked over to their photos. You stared down at yours again realizing you had gotten the Asian one! However he couldnt be serious....right?

“The powder on those photos is actually a powerful nanotechnology that is currently rewriting each of your genetic codes to match the image in the photos. All 9 other guys were busy arguing with each other for the next several minutes as you began to panic. You were really going to change were you? You had no idea how to be a girl let alone a busty Asian one! Not wanting to get involved in this debate you went back to your room to think.

Slowly you woke up as you sat up. The heavy new weight on your chest pulling you down. You had thought for a moment that this was all a horrible nightmare. You wanted to stand up and shout, yell at your TV and demand to be changed back but considering your situation you were in place to make demands. You figured if you played along for now you might understand the purpose of this game Mr. Shadow was playing.

“Greetings Akane! Yes that is your new name. In the deck to your left you will find your new identity and personality profile!” Mr Shadow said.

Reaching over you grabbed the envelope as you saw a picture of yourself with information listed near it.

Name: Akane Mishima

Born: Tokyo, Japan

Age: 19

Moved to United States at age 10.

Siblings: None

Parents: Moved back to Japan last year.

Personality: Shy, playful, innocent.

Sexual Orientation: straight

The last line confused you as Mr Shadow was quick to speak up.

“Now that you have been assigned a new body you have also been given a new background and backstory. This affects your personality, how you talk, act, and even feel towards others. Your job is to assume his identity to the best of your ability. If you do so and by the end of the 30 days we are convinced in your role, we will change you back if you desire.” Mr Shadow said.

“So I just have to become this Akane girl? Act like she would? Basically become her?” You asked.

“Exactly! The nanotechnology in your system will also assist with that. You will notice how you act and feel towards other people will begin to change. We will also provide you with backstory on your character over time. Here is yoUr first sample.” Mr shadow said.

The TV suddenly began to show images of what looked like flashbacks of Akane’s life.

Akane was raised to believe her best chance at a good life was school so she was forced to study and train daily. She got straight As in school and made Varisty swim team and tennis.

However even through all her success in school Akane struggled with someone, herself. She was teased for looking too much like a boy. Her shirt hair, flat breasts, and no curves made her an easy target. This made her self-esteem much lower.

Whether there was anything that she wished for in life. Akane sighed and simply. “To be seen like a real woman” The boy then smiled and planted a small kiss on her lips. “You cursed me? How....why?” Akane asked.

“I was groomed to be our valedictorian and head of the class. However every time you swiped that honor away from me. Always turning in better papers and projects. 15433222222222.title: Something else

154332222222221.content:
It could have happened to anyone, especially someone who had spent the last night pulling an all-nighter to finish off an important paper that was due in first period. Seriously, what kind of sadist teacher has a paper due in their first period class in the middle of the week?

Let's back up for a moment. Your name is Justin, and you were a senior at Thurston Valley High School. At this stage of the game, most people weren't worrying about their grades, but the paper was a huge part of your grade and you couldn't risk a bad grade, lest you be forced to attend summer school and graduate late. So you stayed up all night working on it, hoping for a sliver of sleep, but you finished with only a few minutes until your alarm went off, so it wasn't worth it. You had a coffee before school, but once you got to second period, your body started to crash and you fell fast asleep on your desk.

Which wasn't a problem because your teacher was out sick, so it was basically a free period. However, as a free period, it meant that everyone was doing their own thing. Some people did work for other classes, some read books, some simply left the room, and some followed your example and slept. But for a group of girls, they spent the period on the most worthy of causes. Doing their makeup.

Or at least one of the group did. Stephanie Wheeler was the queen bee of the school, head cheerleader, homecoming queen, probable prom queen, you name it, she was it. Her two best friends were Kathy Andrews and Lara Miller.

"Are you ever going to finish that masterpiece?" Kathy asked. "Or are you going to be fixing your face up until it sags?"

"Shut up, Kath." Stephanie said. "Just because I take pride in my appearance..."

"Taking pride is one thing, this is crazy. You were just doing it at your locker." Lara added.

"And I want to even out my lipstick. Plus my eyebrows are dreadful." Stephanie started to tweeze her brows. "You should let me do you next."

"I'll pass. I don't trust you with sharp objects near my face." Kathy said.

"You remember the haircut incident of Sophomore year, right?" Lara remarked.

"Come on, it was one time! I'm more careful now!" Stephanie insisted. "I'll prove it. I bet I can tweeze your brows and you won't even notice!"

"Still not doing it." Kathy covered up her eyebrows.

"Fine, I'll do..." Stephanie started to look around the room, until her gaze landed on you. "Justin!"

"Leave him alone, he's asleep." Lara said.

"And if he doesn't wake up, I win the bet." Stephanie started to drag her desk over to yours.

As you lay there snoring, Stephanie began her diligent work.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- --------------------------------

The bell rang at the end of class, startling you awake. You yawned as you slowly awoke to see the rest of the class filing out of the room, including Stephanie Wheeler who was looking at you funny for some reason. Had you been drooling? You quickly wiped your mouth with your sleeve to be sure, before grabbing your bag and heading to your next class. As you passed, you noticed Stephanie and Kathy exchanging something, but didn't pay it any mind.

In your next class...

This was supposed to be the best and most fun time of your life and so far you hadn’t done a great job living up to that.

Maybe that’s what pushed you to enter that contest. The desire for excitement and adventure. You had never won anything so you never thought twice about entering that contest at the local pub. They had a large jar filled with sand from a beautiful remote island. Whoever could guess the closest to the number of grains of sand in the jar would win a free plane ticket and week long stay at the paradise island hotel.

You guessed 10 million. A nice simple round number. An easy guess. To your shock when the announced the correct number your name came up as the closest.

It was probably the happiest moment in your life when they called your name. Never had you won anything before. Which is what made the following moment even more painful.

After you received your ticket you called the hotel to book a room only to find a soul crushing answer come from the resort....

Your ticket was no good....Well actually it was...However it was only valid if you were a female....

Apparently you failed to read the fine print on the contest. The resort and island had been reserved for females only. A modeling agency had reserved the island for the week to scout for new potential bikini models to show off a new line of swimwear for a large company.
